vi_translation: April 4th, 1984. Went to see a movie yesterday. All war movies. A good movie, a ship full of refugees in the Mediterranean was bombed. The whole auditorium was delighted watching a big man swimming, while a helicopter chased after him, first seeing him dive like a dolphin, then seeing him through the scope from the plane, then he was shot full of holes like a sieve, the sea suddenly turned pink, he sank quickly as if the water was being sucked through the holes in his body. When he sank to the bottom, the whole auditorium burst into laughter. Then there was a boat full of children, with another helicopter above. At the bow of the boat was a middle-aged woman, probably Jewish, holding a small child about three years old. The child screamed in fear, burying its head in its mother's chest while she comforted it and tried to shield it with her hand even though she was also scared, her face pale as a leaf. She shielded the child with her hand, as if that could stop the bullets. Then the helicopter dropped a twenty-pound bomb, the explosion was terrifying and the boat shattered into pieces. Then there was a wonderful scene of a child's arm flying up, shooting straight into the sky, probably filmed from the nose of the helicopter, and loud applause erupted from the seats reserved for party members, but from the seats for the proles, a woman suddenly screamed, saying that such scenes shouldn't be shown to children, and kept on until the police had to drag her out. They probably wouldn't do anything; the proles' reactions are always like that, who cares...

tr_translation: April 14, 1948. Last night at the cinema. They were all war movies; in a good one, a ship full of refugees was bombed somewhere in the Mediterranean. The image of a fat, burly man struggling to swim, with a helicopter behind him. It greatly amused the audience; first, we saw the man flailing like a dolphin, then the helicopters entered the firing range, then he was riddled with bullets, and the surrounding seawater turned pink, and as if the holes in his body allowed the water to enter, he suddenly sank. As he sank, the audience was doubled over with laughter, then we saw a rescue boat full of children over which a helicopter was flying. In the front sat a middle-aged woman with a small child of about three years old in her lap, she might have been Jewish, the small child was screaming in fear and trying to bury his head between his mother's breasts as if to hide, the woman, though herself pale with fear, was trying to comfort the child and hugging him as tightly as she could as if she could protect him from the incoming bullets, the helicopter dropped a twenty-kilogram bomb on them, there was a tremendous explosion and the boat was shattered into small pieces, then there was an incredible scene of a child's arm flying towards the sky, a helicopter with a camera on its nose must have captured it, applause broke out in the rows where the Party members were seated, but a woman in the proletarian section of the cinema suddenly started stamping her feet and shouting that they had no right to show this in front of children, no, they can't show this to children, I don't think they did anything to her, no one pays attention to what the proletarians say, typical proletarian reaction, never.

es_translation: April 4, 1984. Last night I was at the flicks. All the movies were about war. There was a very good one about a ship full of refugees being bombed somewhere in the Mediterranean. The audience was greatly amused by shots of a very big and very fat man trying to escape by swimming from a helicopter that was chasing him. First, you saw him in the water splashing around like a turtle, then you saw him through the helicopter's machine gun sights, then you saw him being riddled with bullets and the water around him turning all red, and the fat man sinking as if the water was entering through the holes the bullets had made. People were dying of laughter as the fat man sank into the water, and also at a lifeboat full of children with a helicopter circling around and around. There was a middle-aged woman who could well have been Jewish, sitting in the bow with a child in her arms who might have been about three years old. The child was screaming in great panic, burying his head between the woman's breasts as if trying to hide, and the woman was holding him and comforting him as if she herself were not also terrified, and as if by holding him like that in her arms she could prevent the bullets from reaching him. Then the helicopter dropped a twenty-kilo bomb on the boat, and there wasn't a splinter left of it. What an explosion, but magnificent, and then there was a wonderful close-up of the child's arm flying through the air. en: At this moment his mother was sitting in some place deep down beneath him, with his young sister in her arms. He did not remember his sister at all, except as a tiny, feeble baby, always silent, with large, watchful eyes. Both of them were looking up at him. They were down in some subterranean placeâ€”the bottom of a well, for instance, or a very deep graveâ€”but it was a place which, already far below him, was itself moving downwards. They were in the saloon of a sinking ship, looking up at him through the darkening water. There was still air in the saloon, they could still see him and he them, but all the while they were sinking down, down into the green waters which in another moment must hide them from sight forever. He was out in the light and air while they were being sucked down to death, and they were down there because he was up here. He knew it and they knew it, and he could see the knowledge in their faces. There was no reproach either in their faces or in their hearts, only the knowledge that they must die in order that he might remain alive, and that this was part of the unavoidable order of things.

vi_translation: In the dream, mother was sitting below, very deep, holding his little sister. He completely did not remember anything about the little sister, except that she was a frail child with big eyes, quietly observing, never crying. Both of them were looking at him. They were sitting underground - in the heart of a well, or perhaps in a deep grave - and were descending deeper and deeper. They were sitting in the cabin of a sinking ship and looking up at Winston through the black water. There was still air in the cabin, they could still see him and he could see them, but they were gradually sinking into the blue water and would soon disappear completely. He was outside in the air, in the light, while they were being drawn into death, they were being pulled down because he was up here. He knew it, they knew it too, it was evident on their faces. On their faces or in their hearts, there was no blame, only the understanding that they had to die for him to live because that was the rule.

tr_translation: In his dream, his mother, with his sister in her arms, was sitting somewhere below. He did not remember his sister at all; what remained in his memory was only that she was a weak, tiny baby, always silent, watching everything with her big eyes. Both of them were looking up at him. They were in a dark place, it could have been the bottom of a well or a deep grave, but despite being at the bottom, they were in a place that kept sinking deeper. They were in the hall of a sinking ship submerged in dark waters. There was still air inside, they could see him, and he could see them, but for a while then they would be submerged in the green waters and disappear completely. But he was in the open air, in a bright place, while his brother and mother were approaching death, he was above, so they were at the bottom. He knew this; they knew it too, and he could read it from their faces. There was no blame in their hearts or on their faces; they simply knew that they had to die for him to live, and this was part of the inevitable order.

es_translation: At that moment â€”in the dreamâ€” his mother was sitting in a deep place next to him with his little girl in her arms. Of this sister, Winston only remembered that she was a weak and insignificant little girl, always quiet and with big eyes that fixed on everything. The two of them were in some underground place â€”for example, the bottom of a well or a very deep caveâ€” but it was a place that, already far below him, kept sinking without ceasing. Yes, it was the cabin of a sinking ship and the mother and sister looked at him from the darkness of the waters invading the ship. There was still air in the cabin. His mother and little sister could still see him and he could see them, but they kept sinking without a single moment's pause, falling into the waters, very dark green, which would hide them forever at any moment. Winston, on the other hand, was in the open air and in full light while they were being swallowed by death, and they were sinking because he was up there. Winston knew it and they knew it too, and he discovered this knowledge in their faces. But the expression of the two did not reproach him at all, nor did their hearts â€”he knew itâ€” and only the conviction that they were dying so that he could continue living up there was transparent, and that this was part of the inevitable order of things.

Ba ne ba le mo lefelong le le kwa tlase, sekao, kgotsa lebitla le le tseneletseng, mme e ne e le lefelo le le neng le le kwa tlase ga gagwe, le ne le le kwa tlase ga gagwe. Ba ne ba le mo salong ya mokoro o o se nang sepe, ba mo lebile ka metsi a a lefifi. 18Ba ne ba sa ntse ba mmone, mme ene a sa ntse a le teng, mme ba ntse ba itihela fatshe, ba theohela metsing a matala, ao ka nako e nngwe a tshwanetseng ho ba patela ho bona ka ho sa feleng. mg: Tamin'izay fotoana izay dia nipetraka teo amin'ny toerana lalina teo ambaniny ny reniny, niaraka tamin'ny anabaviny mbola kely teny an-tsandriny. Tsy nahatsiaro ny anabaviny mihitsy izy, afa-tsy toy ny zazakely kely sy malemy, mangina foana, manana maso lehibe sy miambina. Samy nijery azy izy roa lahy. Nidina tany amin'ny toerana ambanin'ny tany izy ireoâ€”ny fanambanin'ny lavadrano iray, ohatra, na fasana lalina irayâ€”saingy toerana iray izay efa lavitra azy sahady, dia efa nidina nidina izy. Tao anatin'ny saloon'ny sambo rendrika izy ireo, nijery azy tao anatin'ilay rano maizina. Mbola nisy rivotra ihany tao amin'ny saloon, mbola afaka nahita azy sy izy ireo ihany izy ireo, saingy nandritra ny fotoana rehetra nilentika izy ireo, dia nidina tany amin'ny rano maitso izay tsy maintsy hanafina azy ireo amin'ny fotoana hafa tsy ho hitan'ny maso mandrakizay. Nivoaka tao anatin'ny hazavana sy ny rivotra izy raha mbola minono ho faty izy ireo, ary nidina tany izy ireo satria niakatra teto izy. Fantany izany ary fantatr'izy ireo izany, ary afaka nahita ny fahalalana teo amin'ny endrik'izy ireo izy. Ary tsy nisy latsa na teny amin'ny tarehiny, na tao am-pony, afa-tsy ny fahalalana fa tsy maintsy ho faty izy mba ho velona izy, ary izany dia ampahany amin'ny lamina tsy azo ihodivirana ny zavatra.

en: Suddenly he was standing on short springy turf, on a summer evening when the slanting rays of the sun gilded the ground. The landscape that he was looking at recurred so often in his dreams that he was never fully certain whether or not he had seen it in the real world. In his waking thoughts he called it the Golden Country. It was an old, rabbit-bitten pasture, with a foot track wandering across it and a molehill here and there. In the ragged hedge on the opposite side of the field the boughs of the elm trees were swaying very faintly in the breeze, their leaves just stirring in dense masses like womenâ€™s hair. Somewhere near at hand, though out of sight, there was a clear, slow-moving stream where dace were swimming in the pools under the willow trees.

The black trees by the fence on the opposite side swayed slowly, like thick women's hair, back and forth in the gentle breeze. es_translation: Suddenly, he found himself standing on the grass on a summer afternoon when the oblique rays of the sun gilded the short grass. The landscape that now appeared before him presented itself so frequently in dreams that he was never completely sure if he had ever seen it in real life. When he was awake, he called it the Golden Country. It was covered with grass nibbled by rabbits with a path winding through it and, here and there, some tiny elevations of the terrain. In the background, some elms swayed gently with the breeze, and their foliage looked like women's hair. Nearby, though out of sight, ran a clear, slow-flowing stream.

en: His earlier thought returned to him: probably she was not actually a member of the Thought Police, but then it was precisely the amateur spy who was the greatest danger of all. He did not know how long she had been looking at him, but perhaps for as much as five minutes, and it was possible that his features had not been perfectly under control. It was terribly dangerous to let your thoughts wander when you were in any public place or within range of a telescreen. The smallest thing could give you away. A nervous tic, an unconscious look of anxiety, a habit of muttering to yourselfâ€”anything that carried with it the suggestion of abnormality, of having something to hide. In any case, to wear an improper expression on your face (to look incredulous when a victory was announced, for example) was itself a punishable offense. There was even a word for it in Newspeak: facecrime, it was called.

tr_translation: His first thought came back; he was probably not a Thought Policeman, but he could be an amateur spy. And the greatest danger would come from them. He didn't know how long the man had been watching him; it could have been five minutes, and during that time, he was not very aware of whether he had controlled his facial expression. It was never right to let your thoughts flow freely within the view of a telescreen or in a public place. The slightest thing; a nervous tic, a sorrowful look, the habit of muttering to oneself, anything that could give the impression of abnormality or that something was being hidden could betray you. Giving your face an inappropriate expression (for example, looking bewildered when a victory was announced) was considered a punishable offense. In Newspeak, there was a word for this too; it was called facecrime.

es_translation: He thought that the girl was probably not a member of the Thought Police, but it was precisely the amateur spies who constituted the greatest danger. Winston did not know how long the young woman had been watching him, but perhaps it had been five minutes. It was very possible that during this time he had not been able to control his gestures perfectly. It was a terrible danger to think while being in a public place or within reach of the telescreen. The smallest detail could betray one. A nervous tic, an unconscious look of anxiety, the habit of talking to oneself under one's breath, anything that revealed the need to hide something. In any case, wearing an improper expression on one's face (for example, looking incredulous when a victory was announced) constituted a punishable act. There was even a word for this in Newspeak: facecrime.

en: When he had gone with that woman it had been his first lapse in two years or thereabouts. Consorting with prostitutes was forbidden, of course, but it was one of those rules that you could occasionally nerve yourself to break. It was dangerous, but it was not a life-and-death matter. To be caught with a prostitute might mean five years in a forced-labor camp: not more, if you had committed no other offense. And it was easy enough, provided that you could avoid being caught in the act. The poorer quarters swarmed with women who were ready to sell themselves. Some could even be purchased for a bottle of gin, which the proles were not supposed to drink. Tacitly the Party was even inclined to encourage prostitution, as an outlet for instincts which could not be altogether suppressed. Mere debauchery did not matter very much, so long as it was furtive and joyless, and only involved the women of a submerged and despised class. The unforgivable crime was promiscuity between Party members. Butâ€”though this was one of the crimes that the accused in the great purges invariably confessed toâ€”it was difficult to imagine any such thing actually happening.

vi_translation: This is the first downfall in the past two years. Of course, engaging with prostitutes is not allowed, but sometimes one can take risks. This is dangerous, but it's not a matter of life and death. Getting caught in the act would only mean five years of hard labor at most, that is if there are no aggravating circumstances. Just don't get caught in a compromising position. The slums are full of women willing to sell themselves. Sometimes just a bottle of gin is enough, as the laborers aren't allowed to drink this kind of liquor. The Party tacitly encourages prostitution because it serves as an outlet for instincts that cannot be suppressed anyway. The act of buying sex itself is not a major issue, but it must be done with women from the poor, despised class and, of course, in secret. Relations between Party members are absolutely unforgivable. Although those oppressed in major purges often confess to this crime, it's hard to imagine it actually happening in reality.

tr_translation: His departure with that woman was the first mistake he had made in two years. Relations with prostitutes were forbidden. However, it was a rule that you could occasionally muster the confidence to break. There were dangers involved, but it was not a matter of life and death. Being caught with a prostitute meant being sent to a forced labor camp for five years. If you hadn't committed another crime before, this was the entire punishment. As long as you could avoid being caught in the act, it was a fairly easy crime to commit. The poor sections of the city were teeming with women ready to sell themselves. You could even buy some of them with a bottle of gin, which was forbidden for the proletarians to drink. Prostitution was tacitly encouraged because it served as a kind of outlet for certain urges that couldn't be completely suppressed. As long as it was secretive and unpleasurable and carried out by women from a despised class, no one really cared. The unforgivable crime was the intimacy among Party members. Although this was one of the crimes constantly exposed during the great purges, it was hard to even think that such a thing could happen.

es_translation: When he was with that woman, it was the first time Winston had fallen in about two years. Of course, any relationship with prostitutes was forbidden, but it was admitted that sometimes, through an act of great bravery, one could allow oneself to break the law. It was dangerous but not a matter of life and death, because being caught with a prostitute only meant five years of forced labor. Never more than five years as long as no other crime had been committed at the same time. Which was great since there was the possibility that one might not be discovered. The poor neighborhoods were full of women willing to sell themselves. The price for some was a bottle of gin, a drink supplied to the proles. Tacitly, the Party leaned towards encouraging prostitution as an outlet for instincts that could not be suppressed. These escapades did not matter politically since they were furtive and sad and only involved women from a submerged and despised class. The unforgivable crime was promiscuity among Party members. But â€”although this was one of the crimes that the accused always confessed to during the purgesâ€” it was almost impossible to imagine that such an outrage could happen.

st: Ha a ne a e-na le mosali eo, e ne e le lekhetlo la pele la ho fela ha hae ka lilemo tse peli kapa ka hare ho eona. Ha e le hantle, ha hoa ka ha e-ba joalo, ho ile ha e-ba le e 'ngoe ea melao eo ka linako tse ling u ka e etsang hore u se ke ua senya. E ne e le kotsi, empa e ne e se taba ea bophelo le lefu. Ho ts'oaroa le seotsoa ho ka bolela lilemo tse hlano kampong ea mosebetsi o qobelloang: eseng ho feta, haeba u ne u sa etse tlolo e 'ngoe. 'Me ho ne ho le bonolo ka ho lekaneng, hafeela u ka qoba ho tÅ¡oaroa ka ketso eo. Li-10 tsa basali ba neng ba itokiselitse ho li rekisa. Ba bang ba ka ba ba reka ka botlolo ea gin, eo li-proles li neng li sa lokela ho noa. Ka mokhoa o ts'inging, o ne a bile a tÅ¡ekamelo ea ho khothaletsa botekatse, e le mokhoa oa tlhaho o neng o ke ke oa hatelloa ka botlalo. Feela debauchery ne a sa tsotellehe haholo, ha feela e ne e le furtive le thabo, 'me feela a ameha basali ba sehlopha submerged le nyelisitse. Botlokotsebe bo sa tsitsang bo ne bo le teng pakeng tsa ditho tsa setho. tn: Fa a sena go tsamaya le mosadi yo, go ne ga nna le lobaka lwa gagwe lwa ntlha mo dingwageng tse pedi kgotsa go feta. Ka dinako tse dingwe go ne go se na ope yo o ka dirang gore o se ka wa itewa ke motho yo o sa kgoneng go itewa. Go ne go le kotsi, mme e ne e se kgang ya botshelo le loso. Go tshwarwa le seaka go ka raya dingwaga di le tlhano mo bothibelelong jwa tiro e e patelesegang: e seng go feta, fa o ne o se na molato ope o sele. Le fa go ntse jalo, go ne go le motlhofo gore o se ka wa tshwarwa mo tirong eno. Basadi ba ba humanegileng ba ne ba na le basadi ba ba neng ba ikemiseditse go ithekisa. Ba bangwe ba ne ba ka nna ba bo ba rekwa ka leswÃª le le neng le sa tshwanela go nwa. Ka jalo, go ne go le thata go rotloetsa batho ba ba neng ba sa kgone go nna le seabe mo go direng dilo tse di sa siamang tse di neng di ka se ke tsa nna le seabe mo go one. Le fa go ntse jalo, go ne go sa kgathalasege gore go ne go le thata go dira jalo, go ne go se na ope yo o neng a le mo maemong a a kwa tlase, mme o ne a sa kgone go nna le seabe fela mo basading ba ba nang le maemo a a kwa tlase le a a sa siamang. Bosenyi jo bo sa itshwarelweng bo ne bo le teng magareng ga maloko a setlhopha. Le fa go ntse jalo, go ne go le thata go lemoga gore go ne go le thata go dira jalo ka gonne go ne go le thata go akanya gore go ne go le thata go dira jalo.

mg: Rehefa nandeha niaraka tamin'io vehivavy io izy dia io no tsy fahombiazany voalohany tao anatin'ny roa taona na teo amin'izany. Mazava ho azy fa voarara ny fiarahana amin'ny mpivaro - tena, nefa iray amin'ireo fitsipika azonao atao indraindray ny mikorontan - tsaina. Nampidi-doza izany, saingy tsy resaka fiainana sy fahafatesana izany. Mety hidika dimy taona any amin'ny toby fiasana an-terivozona ny hoe tratra miaraka amin'ny mpivaro-tena: tsy mihoatra, raha tsy nanao heloka hafa ianao. Ary mora izany, raha toa ka afaka misoroka ny ho tratran'ilay fihetsika ianao. Ireo faritra mahantra dia feno vehivavy izay vonona ny hivarotra ny tenany. Ny sasany aza dia azo vidiana amin'ny tavoahangy gin, izay tsy tokony ho sotroin'ny proles. Mirona handrisika ny fivarotan-tena mihitsy aza ny antoko, ho toy ny sehatra ho an'ny fahaizana voajanahary izay tsy azo foanana tanteraka. Tsy dia nanan-danja loatra ny filibana fotsiny, raha mbola tsy nisy fahatezerana sy tsy nisy fifaliana izany, ary ireo vehivavy avy amin'ny saranga tsy dia misy dikany loatra sy tsy misy dikany ihany no tafiditra amin'izany. Ny heloka bevava tsy azo avela dia ny tsy fahaiza-manao eo amin'ireo mpikambana ao amin'ny antoko. Saingyâ€”na dia iray amin'ireo heloka bevava izay nibabohan'ilay voampanga tamin'ny fanadiovana lehibe hatrany aza izanyâ€”sarotra ny haka sary an-tsaina ny hitrangan'izany zavatra izany.

Le fa go ntse jalo, go ka tswa go ne go sa tlhole go na le dilo tse di neng di sa tlhole di le botlhokwa thata le tse di sa ntseng di le botlhokwa thata. Le fa go ntse jalo, e ne e se dilo tse di diragetseng mo nakong e e fetileng fela, mme di ne tsa fetoga ka tsela e e sa fetogeng. en: He picked up the childrenâ€™s history book and looked at the portrait of Big Brother which formed its frontispiece. The hypnotic eyes gazed into his own. It was as though some huge force were pressing down upon youâ€”something that penetrated inside your skull, battering against your brain, frightening you out of your beliefs, persuading you, almost, to deny the evidence of your senses. In the end the Party would announce that two and two made five, and you would have to believe it. It was inevitable that they should make that claim sooner or later: the logic of their position demanded it. Not merely the validity of experience, but the very existence of external reality was tacitly denied by their philosophy. The heresy of heresies was common sense. And what was terrifying was not that they would kill you for thinking otherwise, but that they might be right. For, after all, how do we know that two and two make four? Or that the force of gravity works? Or that the past is unchangeable? If both the past and the external world exist only in the mind, and if the mind itself is controllableâ€”what then?

vi_translation: He held a children's history book and gazed at the picture of Big Brother illustrated on the first page. The hypnotic eyes stared straight at him. It was as if an invisible force was pressing down on him, penetrating his cortex, pounding incessantly on his brain, threatening to force him to abandon his own beliefs, persuading him to even abandon his own senses. In the end, the Party could declare that two plus two equals five and the people would be forced to believe it. Sooner or later they would declare it, their power demanded it. Their philosophy not only implicitly denied the value of experience but also denied objective reality itself. The most nonsensical of nonsense had become reasonable. The scariest thing was not that they would kill you for thinking differently but that they might be right. How do we really know that two plus two is four? Or how do we know there is gravity? How do we know that the past cannot be changed? Or what if the past and the outside world only exist in the mind and the mind can be controlled?
vi_translation_results:
Based on the passage, I'm going to take a guess that the book is "1984" by George Orwell.

The themes of government control, manipulation of reality, and the blurring of objective truth are all characteristic of Orwell's dystopian novel. The mention of "Big Brother" and the Party's ability to declare absurdities as truth also aligns with the book's depiction of a totalitarian regime.

tr_translation: He took the history book written for children. He looked at the picture of Big Brother on the cover. He looked into those chilling eyes. It was as if a great force was applying pressure on you; drilling into your skull and hammering your brain, ripping out your beliefs, forcing you not to believe even in your five senses. In the end, the Party would announce that two plus two equals five, and people would have to believe it. This claim would eventually be put forward; the logic of their situation required it. Not only the validity of experiences but even the existence of external realities was denied by their thought systems. The only way to oppose doctrines that opposed reality was not to part from common sense. What was frightening was not being killed for thinking differently, but the possibility that they might be right. How did we know that two plus two equals four? Or the validity of the law of gravity? Or that the past could not be altered? If the past and the external world only existed in our minds and the mind itself could be controlled...Then what was the use of this investigation?
tr_translation_results: "Title": "1984", "Author": "George Orwell"
es_translation: He took the children's textbook and looked at the portrait of Big Brother that filled the cover. The hypnotic eyes locked onto his. It was as if an immense force began to crush him, something that penetrated his skull, pounded his brain from within, terrified him, and almost persuaded him that it was night when it was day. In the end, the Party would announce that two and two make five and it would have to be believed. It was inevitable that one day it would come to two and two make five. The logic of their position demanded it. Their philosophy denied not only the validity of experience but also the existence of external reality. The greatest heresy was common sense. And the most terrible thing was not that one would be killed for thinking differently, but that they might be right. Because, after all, how do we know that two and two are indeed four? Or that the force of gravity exists. Or that the past cannot be altered. What if the past and the external world only exist in our minds and, since the mind is controllable, the past and what we call reality can also be controlled?
es_translation_results: "Title": "1984", "Author": "George Orwell"

tn: O ne a tsaya buka ya hisetori ya bana mme a leba setshwantsho sa Big Brother, se se neng se dira gore go nne le thulaganyo ya gagwe ya pele. 'The hypnotic eyes in her own' - DitlhÃ´bwÃª di ne di lebile ka boena 10 Le fa go ntse jalo, go ne go sa ntse go na le sengwe se se neng se gopotsa mo teng ga gago, se se go tshosang ka ntlha ya se o se dumelang, se se go tlhotlheletsang gore o se ka wa akanya ka dilo tse o di dumelang. Kwa bokhutlong, o ne a tlhalosa gore bobedi le bone ba ne ba le babedi, mme o tla tshwanelwa ke go dumela seo. Go ne go sa kgonege gore ba kgone go dira kopo eno ka bonako kgotsa moragonyana fela: tsela e ba lebang dilo ka yone. Ga se fela go nna le kitso e e tlhotlheleditsweng, mme go nna le kitso e e molemo ya go nna teng ga ditshedi tsa kwa ntle e ne ya ganediwa ke filosofi ya bone ka tsela e e sa tshwanelang. Go ne go na le moo, go ne go tlwaelegile gore motho a ikutlwe ka tsela e e sa tlwaelegang. Mme se se neng se tshosa e ne e se gore ba tla go bolaya ka go akanya ka tsela e sele, mme e le gore ba siame. Ke eng se se bontshang gore batho ba babedi le ba babedi ba ba nang le dingwaga di le nnÃ¨? A ke maatla a magolo a magolo a a dirang? A dilo tse di diragetseng mo nakong e e fetileng di ka se fetoge? Fa e le gore dilo tse di fetileng le tsa bogologolo di ne di le teng mo mogopolong fela, mme fa mogopolo o ka bo o le mo taolong, o ka dira eng?

mg: Naka ny bokin'ny tantaran'ny ankizy izy ary nijery ny sarin'ny Big Brother izay namorona ny fonony. Ny maso hypnotic dia nijery ny tenany. Toy ny hoe nisy hery goavana nanindry anaoâ€”zavatra izay niditra tao anatin'ny hazon-dohanao, namely ny atidohanao, nampitahotra anao tamin'ny finoanao, nandresy lahatra anao saika handÃ  ny porofon'ny fahatsapanao. Amin'ny farany dia hanambara ny Antoko fa roa sy roa no nanao dimy, ary tsy maintsy mino izany ianao. Tsy azo ihodivirana ny tokony hanaovan'izy ireo izany filazana izany na ho ela na ho haingana: ny lojikan'ny toerana misy azy ireo dia mitaky izany. Tsy ny fahamarinan'ny traikefa fotsiny ihany, fa ny fisian'ny zava-misy ivelany dia nolavin'ny filozofian'izy ireo an-kitsirano. Nitovy hevitra tamin'ny olona ny mpivadi - pinoana. Ary ny nampihoron-koditra dia tsy ny namonoany anao noho ny fieritreretana zavatra hafa, fa mba ho marina izy ireo. Fa ahoana no ahafantarantsika fa ny roa sy ny roa dia manao efatra? Sa miasa ny herin'ny sinton'ny tany? Sa ny lasa tsy miova? Raha ny lasa sy ny tontolo ivelany ihany no misy ao an-tsaina, ary raha ny saina mihitsy no fehezina-ahoana dia?

en: He walked on. The bomb had demolished a group of houses two hundred meters up the street. A black plume of smoke hung in the sky, and below it a cloud of plaster dust in which a crowd was already forming round the ruins. There was a little pile of plaster lying on the pavement ahead of him, and in the middle of it he could see a bright red streak. When he got up to it he saw that it was a human hand severed at the wrist. Apart from the bloody stump, the hand was so completely whitened as to resemble a plaster cast.

en: Whatever was written on the paper, it must have some kind of political meaning. So far as he could see there were two possibilities. One, much the more likely, was that the girl was an agent of the Thought Police, just as he had feared. He did not know why the Thought Police should choose to deliver their messages in such a fashion, but perhaps they had their reasons. The thing that was written on the paper might be a threat, a summons, an order to commit suicide, a trap of some description. But there was another, wilder possibility that kept raising its head, though he tried vainly to suppress it. This was, that the message did not come from the Thought Police at all, but from some kind of underground organization. Perhaps the Brotherhood existed after all! Perhaps the girl was part of it! No doubt the idea was absurd, but it had sprung into his mind in the very instant of feeling the scrap of paper in his hand. It was not till a couple of minutes later that the other, more probable explanation had occurred to him. And even now, though his intellect told him that the message probably meant deathâ€”still, that was not what he believed, and the unreasonable hope persisted, and his heart banged, and it was with difficulty that he kept his voice from trembling as he murmured his figures into the speakwrite.

vi_translation: No matter what the paper says, it is just a political matter. As he understands it, there are two possibilities. First, the more plausible possibility, she is an informant for the Thought Police, just as he has feared all along. He just doesn't understand why the Thought Police would choose to deliver the message in this way, but there must be some reason for it. The message could be a threat, a summons, an order to commit suicide, or it could be a trap. The other possibility, harder to accept, he has tried to dismiss but it keeps resurfacing in his mind. There is a possibility that the message is not from the Thought Police but from some secret organization. Could the Brotherhood still exist! She is a member of it! This is completely illogical, but the thought appeared as soon as he realized he was holding the paper in his hand. It took a few minutes for the first, more plausible possibility to appear in his mind. Even now, although his mind tells him that the paper might signal impending death, he doesn't believe it and, though baseless, he still hopes, his heart pounding, he has to try his best to keep his voice steady and continue reading the numbers into the recorder.
vi_translation_results:
Based on the passage, I'm going to take a guess that the book is "1984" by George Orwell.

The mention of the "Thought Police" and the protagonist's fear of being monitored and controlled by the government suggests a dystopian theme, which is consistent with the themes of "1984". Additionally, the mention of a secret organization called the "Brotherhood" also matches with the plot of "1984", where the Brotherhood is a rebel group fighting against the totalitarian government.
tr_translation: The things written on the paper undoubtedly carried a political content. As far as he could think, there were two possibilities: The first, which was the most likely, was that the girl, as he suspected, could be an agent of the Thought Police. But he couldn't understand why the Thought Police would choose such a strange way to send a message; perhaps they had their own reasons. The things written on the paper could be a threat, a call, an order to commit suicide, or a trap. But there was one more possibility that kept circling in his mind and that he tried to suppress. The message could be coming not from the Thought Police but from a secret underground organization. Maybe the Brotherhood There was such a thing! Maybe the girl was a member of it. This thought was undoubtedly absurd, but the moment she handed him that paper, it crossed his mind. A more plausible possibility occurred to him only a few minutes later. Even now, although his logic told him that this notice meant death, he still couldn't believe it, and for some unknown reason, there was an empty hope inside him. His heart was beating rapidly. While murmuring the list of values, he couldn't prevent his voice from trembling.

The mention of the "Thought Police" and the "Brotherhood" suggests a dystopian novel, and the themes of surveillance, control, and rebellion are all consistent with Orwell's classic work. Additionally, the tone and style of the passage seem to match Orwell's writing style.

es_translation: The words contained in the paper would certainly have a political meaning. There were two possibilities, Winston calculated. One, the most likely, was that the girl was an agent of the Thought Police, as he feared. He did not know why the Thought Police would use this method to deliver their messages, but they could have their reasons for it. What was written on the paper could be a threat, an order to commit suicide, a trap... But there was another possibility, although Winston tried to convince himself that it was madness: that this message did not come from the Thought Police, but from some clandestine organization. Perhaps there was a Brotherhood! Perhaps that girl was one of its members! The idea was absurd, but it had occurred to him the moment he felt the touch of the paper in his hand. It was not until a few minutes later that he thought of the other, much more sensible possibility. And even now, although his head told him that the message would probably mean death, he could not quite believe it and persisted in his absurd hope. His heart was pounding and it took a great effort to keep his voice from trembling while he murmured the amounts into the speakwrite.

Ha ho pelaelo hore mohopolo oo e ne e le oa bohlanya, empa o ne o hlahile kelellong ea hae hanghang hang-hang oa ho utloa pampiri e phepheng letsohong la hae. tn: Sengwe le sengwe se se kwadilweng mo pampiring, se tshwanetse go nna le bokao bongwe jwa sepolitiki. O ne a itse gore go ne go na le ditshono di le pedi tse di ka kgonagalang. Le fa go ntse jalo, go ne go na le sengwe se se neng sa dira gore mosetsana yono e nne ene yo o neng a le mo kotsing, fela jaaka a ne a boifa. O ne a sa itse gore ke ka ntlha yang fa ba ne ba sa itse gore ke ka ntlha yang fa ba ne ba tshwanetse go dirisa melaetsa ya bone ka tsela e e tshwanang, mme gongwe ba ne ba na le mabaka a a utlwalang. Selo se se neng se kwadilwe mo pampiring e ka nna matshosetsi, go bitsa, go bitsa, taelo ya go ipolaya, serai sa tlhaloso nngwe. Le fa go ntse jalo, go ne go na le kgonagalo e nngwe e e neng e sa ntse e le teng, e e neng ya tswelela e gola, le fa a ne a leka ka natla go e gatelela. Seno se ne se sa dira gore go nne le molaetsa o o tswang kwa mapodiseng a a neng a le mo go one, mme go tswa mo mokgatlhong mongwe o o rileng wa ka fa tlase ga lefatshe. Watashi ga Mondanda! Gongwe mosadi yole o ne a le karolo ya gagwe. Le fa go ntse jalo, go ne go se na pelaelo gore go ne go utlwala sentle gore o ne a tsenwa ke tlhaloganyo ka bonako fela fa a ne a le mo tlhogong ya gagwe. Go ne go se na metsotso e le mmalwa morago ga moo, go ne go na le tlhaloso e e oketsegileng e e mo diragaletseng. Le fa go ntse jalo, le fa go ntse jalo, le fa go ntse jalo, go ka direga gore molaetsa o ne o kaya loso,+ e ne e se se se a se dumelang, mme tsholofelo e e sa utlwaleng e e sa itumediseng, pelo ya gagwe e ne ya tswelela pele, mme e ne e le ka bothata jwa gore o ne a dira gore lentswe la gagwe le se ka la roroma fa a ne a ngongorega ka go bua.

mg: Na inona na inona voasoratra tao amin'ny gazety, dia tsy maintsy misy dikany ara-politika izany. Raha ny fahitana azy dia misy safidy roa. Ny iray, izay azo inoana kokoa, dia ny hoe mpiasan'ny Polisin'ny Thought ilay zazavavy, araka ny natahorany. Tsy fantany ny antony tokony hisafidianan'ny Polisy Thought ny hampita ny hafatr'izy ireo amin'ny fomba toy izany, saingy angamba nanana ny antony izy ireo. Ny zavatra voasoratra tao amin'ny gazety dia mety ho fandrahonana, fampiantsoana, didy hamono tena, fandriky ny famaritana sasany. Saingy nisy zavatra hafa mety ho azo atao kokoa izay tsy nitsahatra ny nampitraka ny lohany, na dia niezaka mafy ny hanafoana izany aza izy. Izany hoe, tsy avy amin'ny Thought Police mihitsy ilay hafatra, fa avy amin'ny karazana fikambanana ambanin'ny tany. Angamba efa nisy tokoa ny Firahalahiana! Angamba anisan'izany ilay ankizivavy! Tsy isalasalana fa tsy mitombina ilay hevitra, saingy tonga tao an-tsainy izany tao anatin'ny fotoana fohy dia nahatsapa ilay sombin-taratasy teny an-tÃ nany. Vao minitra vitsy taty aoriana vao tonga taminy ny fanazavana iray hafa izay azo inoana kokoa. Ary na dia ankehitriny aza, na dia nilaza taminy aza ny faharanitan-tsainy fa mety midika ho fahafatesana ilay hafatraâ€”kanefa tsy izany no ninoany, ary nitohy ny fanantenana tsy misy antony, ary nidobodoboka ny fony, ary sarotra taminy ny nanakana ny feony tsy hangovitra rehefa nimonomonona tamin'ny soratra izy.

mg: Ambonin'ny zavatra rehetra tiany ho re izany. Tsy ny fitiavan'ny olona iray ihany, fa ny fironan'ny biby, ny faniriana tsotra tsy misy dikany: izany no hery izay mety handrava ny Antoko. Nanery azy teo amin'ny bozaka izy, teo anivon'ireo lakolosy manga. Tamin'ity indray mitoraka ity dia tsy nisy ny olana. Amin'izao fotoana izao, ny fiakarany sy ny fianjeran'ny tratrany dia niadana ho amin'ny hafainganam-pandeha mahazatra, ary tamin'ny karazana tsy fahafahana mahafinaritra dia nianjera izy ireo. Toa miha-mafana ny masoandro. Samy natory izy roa lahy. Nanolo-tanana izy mba hahazo ireo akanjo ankapobeny nariana ary nisintona azy ireo tamin'ny ampahany teo amboniny. Natory teo no ho eo izy ireo ary natory nandritra ny antsasak'adiny.

en: He thought of the telescreen with its never-sleeping ear. They could spy upon you night and day, but if you kept your head you could still outwit them. With all their cleverness they had never mastered the secret of finding out what another human being was thinking. Perhaps that was less true when you were actually in their hands. One did not know what happened inside the Ministry of Love, but it was possible to guess: tortures, drugs, delicate instruments that registered your nervous reactions, gradual wearing-down by sleeplessness and solitude and persistent questioning. Facts, at any rate, could not be kept hidden. They could be tracked down by inquiry, they could be squeezed out of you by torture. But if the object was not to stay alive but to stay human, what difference did it ultimately make? They could not alter your feelings; for that matter you could not alter them yourself, even if you wanted to. They could lay bare in the utmost detail everything that you had done or said or thought; but the inner heart, whose workings were mysterious even to yourself, remained impregnable.

vi_translation: He thought about the screen with the radio receiver that was on twenty-four hours a day. They could monitor day and night, but if one was alert, they could still be deceived. No matter how clever they were, they could never know what one was thinking. Falling into their hands was a different story. No one knew what happened in the Ministry of Love, only guesses: torture, drugs, sophisticated devices that could record nervous system reactions, exhaustion from sleep deprivation, loneliness, and continuous interrogation. Facts could not be hidden. They would find out through interrogation, they would torture until they succeeded. But if the goal was not to live but to remain human, it was different; what could they do to us? They could not change our feelings; if we couldn't change our own feelings, how could they? They could extract everything, they could know in detail what we did, said, and thought, but our soul, its workings were a mystery even to ourselves, and no one could penetrate it. tr_translation: He thought about the ever-awake ears of the telescreen. Even if they watched you day and night, as long as you kept your composure, you could defeat them. Despite all their cunning, they couldn't solve the secret of reading what goes on in a human's mind. Perhaps this wasn't valid when you fell into their hands. No one knew what happened in the Ministry of Love, but they could guess; tortures, drugs, sensitive devices measuring your reactions, sleeplessness, loneliness, and bodies exhausted from constant interrogation. At the very least, you couldn't hide concrete facts. They would find these out by investigating, they would extract them from you through torture. But if the goal was not to live, but to remain human, what importance could that have? They couldn't change your feelings; even you yourself couldn't change them, even if you wanted to. They could reveal everything you did, said, or thought in the finest detail, but they couldn't reach that deep place in your heart, the place whose workings even you didn't know.

es_translation: And he thought about the telescreen, which never slept, which never got distracted nor stopped listening. They could spy on someone day and night, but by not losing one's head, it was possible to outsmart them. With all their skill, they had never managed to find a way to know what another human being was thinking. Perhaps this was less true when they had someone in their hands. No one knew what happened inside the Ministry of Love, but it was easy to imagine: tortures, drugs, delicate instruments that recorded nervous reactions, progressive exhaustion from lack of sleep, from solitude, and from relentless and persistent interrogations. The facts could not be hidden; they were squeezed out of someone with torture or tracked down with interrogations. But if the goal one set was not to save one's life but to have been human until the end, what did all that matter? Feelings could not be changed; moreover, not even oneself could suppress them. Without a doubt, they could know even the smallest detail of everything someone had done, said, or thought; but the depths of the heart, whose content was a mystery even to its owner, would always remain impregnable.

Ka bohlale bohle ba bona, ha baa ka ba tseba sephiri sa ho tseba hore na motho e mong o nahana eng. Mohlomong sena se ne se le tlase haholo ha o ne o le matsohong a bona. Motho o ne a sa tsebe se etsahetseng kahare ho Lekala la Lerato, empa ho ne ho khonahala ho nahana: tlhokofatso, lithethefatsi, lisebelisoa tse thata tse ngolisitseng liphetoho tsa hau tsa methapo, ho apara butle-butle ke ho hloka boroko le bolutu le ho ipotsa lipotso tse phehellang. tn: O ne a akanya ka mogala wa gagwe o o sa robaleng. Ba ne ba ka nna ba go bolaya mo bosigong le motshegare, mme fa o ka bo o sa ntse o le mo sephiring. Le fa go ntse jalo, ba ne ba sa itse gore ke eng se motho yo mongwe a se akanyang. Gongwe go ne go le thata fa o ne o le mo diatleng tsa gago. O ne a sa itse gore go diragetse eng mo Lefapheng la Lorato, mme go ne go kgonega go akanya: tlhokofatso, diokobatsi, didirisiwa tse di sa siamang tse di neng tsa kwadisa tsela e o ikutlwang ka yone, go apara ka bonya ka go tlhoka boroko le go ipotsa. Boammaaruri ke gore, ka tsela nngwe, ga go na sepe se se ka nnang sa fitlhega. Ba ka nna ba tlhotlhomisiwa, ba ka nna ba tlhotlhomisiwa ka ntlha ya tlhokofatso. Le fa go ntse jalo, fa go ne go se na sepe se se neng sa dira gore motho a se ka a tshela, o ne a dira pharologanyo efe? O ne a sa kgone go fetola tsela e o ikutlwang ka yone. Le fa go ntse jalo, o ne o ka se kgone go di fetola, le fa o batla go di dira. O ka tlhalosa sengwe le sengwe se o se buileng kgotsa se o se akantseng. Le fa go ntse jalo, tiro ya bone e ne e le e e sa tlwaelegang, e ne e le ya boitshetlha, e ne e sa ntse e le ka tsela e e sa tlwaelegang.

mg: Nieritreritra ny telescreen miaraka amin'ny sofiny tsy matory mihitsy izy. Afaka mitsikilo anao andro aman'alina izy ireo, saingy raha mitazona ny lohanao ianao dia mbola afaka manoatra azy ireo. Na dia teo aza ny faharanitan-tsain'izy ireo dia tsy nahafehy ny tsiambaratelon'ny fahafantarana izay eritreretin'ny olombelona hafa mihitsy izy ireo. Angamba tsy dia marina loatra izany raha tena teo an-tÃ nan'izy ireo ianao. Tsy nisy nahafantatra izay nitranga tao anatin'ny Minisiteran'ny Fitiavana, saingy azo novinavinaina izany: fampijaliana, zava-mahadomelina, fitaovana marefo izay nandrakitra ny fihetseham-ponao mitaintaina, ny tsy fahampian'ny torimaso sy ny fitokana-monina ary ny fanontaniana maharitra. Na ahoana na ahoana, tsy azo afenina ny zava-misy. Azo atao ny manara-maso azy ireo amin'ny alalan'ny fanadihadiana, mety ho voatosika hiala aminao amin'ny alalan'ny fampijaliana izy ireo. Raha tsy ny hijanona ho velona anefa no tanjona, fa ny hijanona ho olombelona, inona no fiovana nentin'izany tamin'ny farany? Tsy afaka nanova ny fahatsapanao izy ireo; Amin'ity tranga ity dia tsy afaka manova azy ireo ianao, na dia tianao aza izany. Afaka milaza amin'ny antsipiriany amin'ny antsipiriany ny zavatra rehetra nataonao na nolazainao na noeritreretinao izy ireo; Fa ny fo anatiny, izay zava-miafina na dia ny tenanao aza dia mbola tsy azo atao.

en: To understand the nature of the present warâ€”for in spite of the regrouping which occurs every few years, it is always the same warâ€”one must realize in the first place that it is impossible for it to be decisive. None of the three superstates could be definitively conquered even by the other two in combination. They are too evenly matched, and their natural defenses are too formidable. Eurasia is protected by its vast land spaces. Oceania by the width of the Atlantic and the Pacific, Eastasia by the fecundity and industriousness of its inhabitants. Secondly, there is no longer, in a material sense, anything to fight about. With the establishment of self-contained economies, in which production and consumption are geared to one another, the scramble for markets which was a main cause of previous wars has come to an end, while the competition for raw materials is no longer a matter of life and death. In any case, each of the three superstates is so vast that it can obtain almost all the materials that it needs within its own boundaries. In so far as the war has a direct economic purpose, it is a war for labor power. Between the frontiers of the superstates, and not permanently in the possession of any of them, there lies a rough quadrilateral with its corners at Tangier, Brazzaville, Darwin, and Hong Kong, containing within it about a fifth of the population of the earth. It is for the possession of these thickly populated regions, and of the northern ice cap, that the three powers are constantly struggling. In practice no one power ever controls the whole of the disputed area. Portions of it are constantly changing hands, and it is the chance of seizing this or that fragment by a sudden stroke of treachery that dictates the endless changes of alignment.

vi_translation: To understand the nature of the current war - even though allies and enemies change every few years, it remains a war - we must always remember that this war has no end. Even if the armies of two countries join forces, they cannot defeat the third country. Their strengths are nearly equivalent, and their natural defenses are extremely solid. Eurasia is surrounded by vast lands, Oceania is protected by the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans, and Eastasia has a very large and diligent population. Secondly, they do not fight for material benefits. With the establishment of self-sufficient economies, where production and consumption are adjusted to match each other, the competition for markets, the main reason for previous wars, has become unnecessary; meanwhile, raw materials are not a critical issue. All three countries are so large that they can exploit all the necessary raw materials within their own territories. In terms of direct economic purpose, this is a war to gain labor forces. Between the borders of the superpowers lies a quadrilateral region with vertices at Tangier, Brazzaville, Darwin, and Hong Kong, a region that does not wholly belong to any superpower, yet contains one-fifth of the world's population. The competition for this densely populated area and the icy regions of the northern hemisphere is the reason for the frequent disputes between the superpowers. No country has fully occupied the contested region. Parts of it frequently change hands, and to gain control of a particular area, people are willing to betray allies, turn friends into enemies, and this is the reason for the endless changes in alliances.
vi_translation_results: "Title": "1984", "Author": "George Orwell"
tr_translation: To understand the structure of the current war - despite the formation of new clusters every few years, the war is still the same war - it must first be remembered that its certainty is impossible. The three superpowers- Even if two of them unite, they cannot defeat the other. They are equal in terms of strength, and their natural defenses are hard to break. Eurasia relies on its vast lands, Oceania on the expanse of the Pacific and Atlantic, and East Asia on its rapidly growing population and industriousness. Secondly, there is no material gain to be obtained as a result of wars. With the establishment of self-sufficient economies, the struggle for markets, which was the main cause of previous wars, has come to an end. Since all three states can meet their needs within their own borders, the issue of raw materials has lost its importance. If war has an economic purpose, it is labor. Between Tangier, Brazzaville, Darwin, and Hong Kong lie lands containing one-fifth of the world's population, which all three major states strive to capture. No state has been able to control these areas alone. The different parts of the area are constantly changing hands, and this is the reason for the endless shifts in alliances.

es_translation: To understand the nature of the current war â€”for, despite the regrouping that occurs every few years, it is always the same warâ€” one must first realize that this war cannot be decisive. None of the three superstates could be definitively conquered, not even by the other two in combination. Their forces are too well balanced. And their defenses are too powerful. Eurasia is protected by its vast land spaces, Oceania by the width of the Atlantic and the Pacific, East Asia by the fertility and industriousness of its inhabitants. Moreover, there is no longer anything to fight for. With autarkic economies, the struggle for markets, which was one of the main causes of previous wars, has ceased to make sense, and competition for raw materials is no longer a matter of life and death. Each of the three superstates is so immense that it can obtain almost all the materials it needs within its own borders. If anything, the war aims at the domination of labor. Between the borders of the superstates, and without permanently belonging to any of them, there extends a quadrilateral, with its corners in Tangier, Brazzaville, Darwin, and Hong Kong, which contains almost one-fifth of the Earth's population. The three powers constantly fight for the possession of these densely populated regions, as well as for the polar zones. In practice, no power totally controls this disputed area. Portions of it are constantly changing hands, and what actually determines the sudden and multiple changes of alliances is the possibility of seizing one or another piece of land through an unexpected betrayal.

st: Ho utloisisa mofuta oa ntoa ea hajoale ea hajoale, leha ho na le lihlopha tse etsahalang lilemong tse ling le tse ling tse 'maloa, kamehla ntoa e tÅ¡oanang e tlameha ho elelloa sebakeng sa pele hore ho ke ke ha khoneha hore e be ea makhaola-khang. Ha ho le e 'ngoe ea li-superstates tse tharo tse neng li ke ke tsa hlola esita le tse ling tse peli ka kopanelo. Li ts'oana haholo, 'me ts'ireletso ea bona ea tlhaho e tÅ¡abeha haholo. Eurasia e sirelelitsoe ke libaka tsa eona tse kholo tsa naha. Oceania ke bophara ba Atlantic le Pacific, Eastasia ke khotso le ho se tsotelle ha baahi ba eona. Taba ea bobeli, ha ho sa na, ka kutloisiso ea lintho tse bonahalang, eng kapa eng eo u ka e loantÅ¡ang. Ka ho theoa ha moruo o ikemetseng, moo tlhahiso le ts'ebeliso li lebisitsoeng ho e mong, ho scramblea mebarakeng e neng e le sesosa se seholo sa lintoa tse fetileng ho felile, ha tlholisano ea lisebelisoa tse tala e se e le taba ea bophelo le lefu. Leha ho le joalo, e 'ngoe le e' ngoe ea li-superstates tse tharo e kholo hoo e ka bang thepa eohle eo e e hlokang ka har'a meeli ea eona. Ho fihlela ntoa e na le morero o tobileng oa moruo, ke ntoa ea matla a basebetsi. Pakeng tsa meeli ea baphaenehi, eseng ka ho sa feleng ba nang le leha e le efe ea tsona, ho na le quadrilateral e thata e nang le likhutlo tsa eona Tangier, Brazzaville, Darwin le Hong Kong, tse nang le eona hoo e ka bang karolo ea bohlano ea baahi ba lefatÅ¡e. Ke bakeng sa ho rua libaka tsena tse nang le baahi ba bangata haholo, le ea cap ea leqhoa e ka leboea, hore matla a mararo a lula a loana. Ntle le moo, ha ho na motho ea laolang sebaka sohle sa marang-rang. Likarolo tsa eona li lula li fetoha matsoho, 'me ke monyetla oa ho sebetsana le sena kapa hore ho arohana ka tÅ¡ohanyetso ho treachery e laelang liphetoho tse sa feleng tsa ho lumellana.

tn: Go tlhaloganya gore ke eng se se diregang mo dingwageng dingwe le dingwe tse di mmalwa tse di fetileng, go tshwanetse ga bo go le thata gore motho a kgone go dira jalo. Le fa go ntse jalo, ga go na ope wa ba ba neng ba ka kgona go fenya ba bangwe ba bararo le fa e le ba bangwe ba ba neng ba le mo matlhakoreng a mabedi a a farologaneng. Di a tura thata, mme di na le bokgoni jo bo feteletseng jwa go dira gore di nne le seabe mo go feteletseng. Eurasia e sireleditswe ke masimo a yona a mantsintsi. Oceania ka bophara ba Atlantic le Pacific, Eastasia ka bopelotshetlha le bopelotshetlha jwa baagi ba yone. Le fa go ntse jalo, ga go tlhole go na le sengwe se se ka go thusang go lwantshana le ene. Ka go tlhamiwa ga diikonomi tse di nang le boithati, mo mo go yone ntshodikuno le tiriso di diretsweng mongwe, go thukhutha ga mebaraka e e neng e le lebaka le legolo la dintwa tse di fetileng e setse e fedile, fa kgaisano ya didirisiwa tse di tala e sa tlhole e le kgang ya botshelo le loso. Le fa go ntse jalo, nngwe le nngwe ya batho ba le bararo ba ba nang le bokgoni jwa go reka mo e ka nnang teng mo e batlang e le sengwe le sengwe se se tlhokang mo melelwaneng ya sona. Ka jalo, fa ntwa e na le maikaelelo a a tlhamaletseng a ikonomi, ke ntwa ya maatla a a kwa godimo. Fa gare ga melelwane ya batlhanogi, e seng ruri mo go nna le nngwe ya tsone, go na le dikhutlo tse di thata tse di nang le dikhutlo tsa yone kwa Tangier, Brazzaville, Darwin le Hong Kong, tse di mo teng mo go yone e ka nna karolo ya botlhano ya batho ba lefatshe. Ke ka ntlha ya go nna le dikgaolo tse di nang le batho ba le bantsi, le tsa kgaolo ya Bokone, e leng gore maatla a mararo a a lwelwang ka metlha. Le fa go ntse jalo, ga go na ope yo o ka laolang lefatshe lotlhe le le nang le kgotlhang. Ka dinako tse dingwe, go na le kgonagalo ya go dira gore go nne le diphetogo tse di sa khutleng kgotsa tse di ka dirang gore go nne le diphetogo tse di sa feleng tsa go dira gore go nne le diphetogo tse di sa khutleng.

Tsy misy amin'ireo fanjakana telo ireo no azo resy tanteraka na dia ireo roa hafa aza mitambatra. Mitovy loatra izy ireo, ary ny fiarovan-tenany voajanahary dia tena goavana loatra. Voaaro amin'ny velarantany midadasika i Eurasia. Oseania amin'ny sakan'ny Atlantika sy ny Pasifika, atsinanan'i Azia amin'ny alalan'ny fecundity sy ny fahazotoan'ny mponina ao aminy. Faharoa, tsy misy intsony, amin'ny lafiny ara-nofo, na inona na inona mba hiady momba. Miaraka amin'ny fametrahana ny toekarena mifehy tena, izay mifamatotra amin'ny famokarana sy ny fanjifana ny famokarana, dia nifarana ny scramble ho an'ny tsena izay antony lehibe indrindra tamin'ny ady teo aloha, raha toa ka tsy resaka fiainana sy fahafatesana intsony ny fifaninanana ho an'ny akora manta. Na izany na tsy izany, ny tsirairay amin'ireo fanjakana telo dia tena goavana ka afaka mahazo saika ny fitaovana rehetra ilainy ao anatin'ny faritry ny tenany. Raha ny momba ny ady dia manana tanjona ara-toekarena mivantana, dia ady ho an'ny herin'ny mpiasa izany. Eo anelanelan'ny sisin-tanin'ireo fanjakana lehibe, ary tsy maharitra eo amin'ny fananan'izy ireo, dia misy quadrilateral mikitoantoana miaraka amin'ny zorony ao Tangier, Brazzaville, Darwin, ary Hong Kong, izay ahitana ny ampahadimin'ny mponina eto an-tany. Ho an'ny fananana ireo faritra be mponina ireo, sy ny ranomandry any avaratra, no miady tsy tapaka ireo hery telo ireo. Raha ny fanao, tsy misy olona mifehy ny faritra iray manontolo misy adihevitra. Ny ampahany amin'izany dia miova tanana foana, ary izany dia ny fahafahana haka ity sombin-javatra ity na io sombin-javatra io amin'ny alalan'ny famitahana tampoka izay mandidy ny fiovana tsy misy fiafarany amin'ny fampifanarahana.

en: He had still, he reflected, not learned the ultimate secret. He understood how; he did not understand why. Chapter 1, like Chapter 3, had not actually told him anything that he did not know; it had merely systematized the knowledge that he possessed already. But after reading it he knew better than before that he was not mad. Being in a minority, even a minority of one, did not make you mad. There was truth and there was untruth, and if you clung to the truth even against the whole world, you were not mad. A yellow beam from the sinking sun slanted in through the window and fell across the pillow. He shut his eyes. The sun on his face and the girlâ€™s smooth body touching his own gave him a strong, sleepy, confident feeling. He was safe, everything was all right. He fell asleep murmuring â€œSanity is not statistical,â€ with the feeling that this remark contained in it a profound wisdom.

vi_translation: He lay still, continuing to think, thus he still did not know the most important secret. He understood how, but did not understand why. Chapters I and III had nothing new, they only systematized the knowledge he already knew. But after reading, he knew for certain that he was not insane. The minority, even if reduced to just one person, does not mean insanity. Truth and falsehood always exist, if we cling to the truth, even if we have to go against the whole world, we are still not insane. A golden ray of sunlight shone through the window and fell onto the pillow. Winston closed his eyes. The warm sunlight played on his cheek along with the soft touches of the girl's skin, creating in him a feeling of dreamy yet strong trust. He was still safe, everything was still good. He drifted off to sleep, mumbling, "Sanity is not statistical," feeling as if that sentence contained a profound truth. [1]Original text: like three sheaves of corn - like three corn stalks. tr_translation: He had not yet learned the last secret. He understood how it was, but he didn't understand why it was. The first part, too, the third- Like a cÃ¼sÃ¼, it didn't teach him anything new, it only organized the knowledge that he already had. But after reading, he realized that what he thought was not madness. Being in the minority, even if that minority consisted of just one person, did not mean that one was mad. There was truth on one side and lies on the other, and if you held on to the truth even at the cost of opposing the whole world, that did not make you mad. es_translation: â€”Still, he thought, he had not yet discovered what the last secret was. He understood the how; he did not understand the why. Chapter 1, like Chapter III, had not taught him anything he didn't already know. They had only served to systematize the knowledge he already possessed. But after reading those pages, he had a greater certainty that he was not crazy. Being in the minority, even a minority of one, did not mean being crazy. There was the truth and what was not the truth, and if one clung to the truth even against the whole world, one was not crazy. A yellowish ray of the setting sun entered through the window and spread across the pillow. Winston closed his eyes. The sun in his eyes and the soft body of the girl touching his gave him a feeling of sleepiness, strength, and confidence. Everything was fine and he felt completely secure there. He fell asleep with the thought "sanity is not statistical," convinced that this observation contained profound wisdom.

tn: O ne a sa ntse a akanya, a sa itse sephiri sa bofelo. O ne a tlhaloganya gore jang; O ne a sa tlhaloganye lebaka la seo. Kgaolo 1, jaaka Kgaolo 3, o ne a sa mo bolelele sepe se a neng a sa se itse; O ne a bua fela ka kitso e a neng a na le yone. Mme morago ga go bala o ne a itse botoka go na le gore o ne a sa itse gore o a gakaga. Le fa go ntse jalo, le fa e le motho yo o humanegileng, o ne a sa batle go go galefela. 13 Boammaaruri bo ne bo le teng, mme fa lo ka ineela mo boammaaruring le mo lefatsheng lotlhe, ga lo a ka lwa tsenwa. Le fa go ntse jalo, letsatsi le le tlhabang le ne la tswa mo fensetereng mme la wela ka fa tlase ga leswelana. O ne a didimala matlho a gagwe. Letsatsi le le mo mafatlheng a gagwe le mmele wa mosetsana yo o boretheng o ne a mo neela maikutlo a a nonofileng, a robetse, a itshepa. O ne a itekanetse mme dilo tsotlhe di a siama. O ne a tlhalosa fa a ne a robetse a re: "Ga go na sepe se se bontshang gore o na le botlhale jo bo tseneletseng."

Ny toko 1, toy ny Toko faha-3, dia tsy nilaza taminy na inona na inona izay tsy fantany; Namolavola ny fahalalana izay efa nananany fotsiny izany. Saingy rehefa avy namaky izany izy dia nahafantatra tsara kokoa noho ny teo aloha fa tsy tezitra izy. Ny maha-vitsy an'isa, na dia vitsy an'isa aza, dia tsy nahatonga anao ho adala. Nisy ny fahamarinana ary nisy ny tsy fahamarinana, ary raha nifikitra tamin'ny fahamarinana ianao na dia tamin'izao tontolo izao aza, dia tsy tezitra ianao. Nisy andry mavo iray avy amin'ilay masoandro nilentika niditra teo amin'ny varavarankely ary nianjera teo amin'ny ondana. Nakimpiny ny masony. Ny masoandro teo amin'ny tarehiny sy ny vatany malefaka nikasika ny tenany manokana dia nanome azy fahatsapana matanjaka, matory ary matoky tena. Tsy naninona izy, nandeha tsara ny zava-drehetra. en: One day they would decide to shoot him. You could not tell when it would happen, but a few seconds beforehand it should be possible to guess. It was always from behind, walking down a corridor. Ten seconds would be enough. In that time the world inside him could turn over. And then suddenly, without a word uttered, without a check in his step, without the changing of a line in his faceâ€”suddenly the camouflage would be down and bang! would go the batteries of his hatred. Hatred would fill him like an enormous roaring flame. And almost in the same instant bang! would go the bullet, too late, or too early. They would have blown his brain to pieces before they could reclaim it. The heretical thought would be unpunished, unrepented, out of their reach forever. They would have blown a hole in their own perfection. To die hating them, that was freedom.

vi_translation: One day they will shoot you. It can't be said when, but a few seconds before it happens, it can probably be guessed. Always from behind, while walking in the hallway. Ten seconds is enough. In that time, your soul can completely change. And then suddenly, without saying a word, still walking steadily, with an unchanged expression, you tear off the mask, bang! your volley of hatred rings out. Hatred will fill your soul, like a blazing, roaring fire. And at that moment: bang! the bullet flies out, too late or too early. They will blow your brains out before they can reform it. Unorthodox thoughts, not yet subdued, unrepentant, will forever be beyond their reach. Their ideals will have a hole shot through them. To die still hating - that is freedom.

tr_translation: One day, they would decide to kill him. He couldn't say when it would happen, but he could know a few seconds before it did. They always shot him from behind while he was walking down the corridor. Ten seconds were enough. Then, the world inside him would surface, and then suddenly, without saying a single word, without any difference in his steps, without any change in the expression on his face, that veil would lift, and his hatred would violently burst out. Hatred made him strong would fill like a flame. And at that moment, the bullet would fire! The bullet would either find him too early or too late, before they could regain control of his mind, they would have shattered his brain. The stray thought would remain unpunished, it would have escaped their grasp forever. A madness would open in their perfection. To die hating them; that was freedom.

es_translation: Someday they would decide to kill him. It was impossible to know when it would happen, but a few seconds before it could be guessed. They always killed someone from behind while walking down a hallway. But ten seconds would be enough for him. And then, suddenly, without saying a word, without it being noticeable in the steps he still took, without altering his expression... he could drop the camouflage, and bang!, unleash the batteries of his hatred. Yes, in those seconds before his death, his entire being would become an enormous flame of hatred. And almost at the same instant, bang!, the bullet would arrive, too late, or perhaps too soon. They would have destroyed his brain before they could consider it theirs. The heretical thought would remain unpunished. He would not have repented, he would remain forever out of reach of those people. With the shot they would have opened a hole in that perfection they boasted about. To die hating them, that was freedom.

mg: Indray andro dia nanapa-kevitra ny hitifitra azy izy ireo. Tsy afaka milaza ianao hoe rahoviana no hitranga izany, saingy segondra vitsy mialoha dia tokony ho azo atao ny maminavina. Avy any aoriana foana izany, mandeha eny amin'ny lalantsara. Folo segondra dia ampy izay. Amin'izay fotoana izay dia afaka mivadika ny tontolo ao anatiny. Ary tampoka teo, tsy nisy teny notononina, tsy nisy fanaraha-maso tamin'ny diany, tsy nisy fanovana tsipika teo amin'ny tarehinyâ€”tampoka teo dia nidina sy nidobodoboka ilay saron-tava! Ary dia hanodidina anao sy Manodidina anao manodidina. Ny fankahalana dia hameno azy toy ny lelafo mierona. Ary saika ao anatin'ny fotoana fohy ihany! Tara loatra, na aloha loatra. Mety ho nopotehin'izy ireo ny atidohany talohan'ny nahafahan'izy ireo naka izany. Tsy ho voasazy, tsy hibebaka, tsy ho azon'izy ireo mandrakizay, ilay hevitra nivadiham - pinoana. Mety ho nanapoaka lavaka iray tamin'ny fahatanterahany manokana izy ireo. Ny fahafatesana dia fankahalana, izany no fahafahana.
